ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: this course is really an independent project with a seminar series. more attention should be paid to creating more stages for the final project. if you really want the final project to be a research paper then there should be time for hypothesis development and discussion of the ideas along the way, rather than just bunched into the end with little feedback.

This was clearly an experimental class but I think it worked well! Work load was VERY unevenly distributed though - hardly any work in the fall and much more work (because of the paper) in the spring.
Question 8.Very interesting class, but feels like the content of the course is to scattered. I am sure this class would be much improved if it's offered the 2nd time.

This is a very hard course to rate, since it is clear that its unique structure and uncertain demeanor were artifacts of it being experimentation. I acknowledge that the people involved are trying something new, and we desperately need more classes about integrated urban systems at Yale FES, given the massive urbanization that is underway around the world. Such classes would be rigorous and multidisciplinary, with key messages that students can take away. This seemed scattershot.
I really enjoyed the guest speakers
It was really more of a seminar series. Many of the speakers were excellent.
Great speakers and readings.
To have a chance to make a video
Lots of work to bring in speakers. Great format idea

I wasn't optimistic, but the workshop at the end of the class was better than I expected. Karen Seto was able to ask questions that really got people talking. Maybe it was also because we were sitting in a circle and we were relating it to things more relevant to our interests.
I really enjoyed writing my final paper. I thought the TA (Peter Christensen) was incredibly helpful to me during this process. Also I really enjoyed almost every single visiting speaker.
The speakers were great and interesting
The final workshop, where students present their paper findings, and all instructors are trying to connect the topics we learned through-out the year.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: It didn't really feel like a "class". We just sort of attended lectures together. It have been nice to have more class time to discuss themes without the presence of the guest speaker - in a more relaxed environment.
Need to have expectations of students laid out at the beginning.
There were way too many students to have meaningful conversations. This aspect defeated part of the purpose of the class.
I thought the discussions were too unstructured - Perhaps assigning discussion leaders for each week would help to keep the discussion more focused.
Information and communication. Often confusing and late. Scheduling needs to be more in advance.

The class format (lecture series followed by discussion) was frustrating because students weren't able to plan for lectures until a few days before (flexibility was required to work around guest lecturers' schedules) and the topics didn't seem to come together into anything cohesive. Maybe discussion would have been better if Karen Seto was leading it.

Although the visiting speakers were usually quite good, the post-lecture discussions were slow, meandering, and frustrating. The assigned readings did very little to inform the discussion. The professors were not very engaged in leading the discussion in a forward direction, and as a result the students were pretty much unengaged the entire time.
It was a little bit scattered because the courses were every few weeks. More organizational clarity would have been great.

I did not get much out of different guest lectures other than being exposed to a series of interesting perspectives. There could be a way to link these great seminars together better. I would recommend to have an additional workshop scheduled in the late Fall, for people to summarize things learned in the first half of the class and begin to brainstorm research ideas.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: TA was very available to meet when it came time to work on our papers.
The TA was always willing to help.
Peter answered questions (via email) in a timely manner. He also contributed a lot in class but I'm not sure it really guided the discussion in a direction that led to greater class participation.
The TA (Peter Christensen) was hugely helpful. I never approached any of the instructors for help.
Both good, though I never really needed their help since I took it for 1 credit.
The TA was particularly helpful for us.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This course was very relevant to my coursework. I recommend it to anyone who has an uban focus to his/her studies.
to give a taste about urban planning and help me better understand the concepts of industrial ecology
It filled a bin requirement that I needed for graduation.

This course didn't really fit into my overall program. I had hoped that it would, but in retrospect I would have gotten much more from a different type of course (i.e. one that had a developed curriculum, concrete goals, and an articulated program).
I am interested in urbanization broadly and sustainable development. I thought this course would allow me to learn from some thought leaders in the field.
I had a good exposure to exciting topics in the study of urbanization and I was able to link my own academic interests to it. Looking forward to see more urban focus in F&ES in the coming year.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn more about urban issues.
Functional cities will be essential to achieve future social and environmental goals.
To learn about urbanization in depth.
To fill a bin requirement that I needed for graduation.
To learn from thought leaders on MFA, sustainable development, and urban development in developing countries.
Interests in the topic and the format of the class.
I am a student of urban systems planning, and wanted to be in a collaborative environment that allowed me to explore these questions in more depth and from different perspectives.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: No

I wanted to have more time to debate questions around urban issues - something that could have happened if we had had more class time. Since all of our discussions were in the presence of the speaker, people felt compelled to ask the speaker questions so as to engage him/her but I think more unstructured time with just the class and professors would have been better.
No
Not as much as I hoped.
No. I think a regular lecture series from one professor (or a few) would have been much more informative and helpful.
No.
Yeah, the speakers were pretty interesting, but it was hard to really get a lot out of it since the courses were so spaced out from each other.
Yes
Not really.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I had no expectations because it was the first time it was being taught but I was pleasantly surprised!
No
the course can be finished in one semester
Yes, I got my bin requirement! Not sure what else I expected.
No.
Mostly
I could get more out of the guest lectures.
No, see Question 11.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I thought that the group work was a little bit more than should be required for just one credit.
too little requirement/workload for 1 credit students
I did like the interview aspect of the course, and it was nice preparing questions and helping to conduct an interview. Practical skills and hopefully a real result, too.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If they do the same timing - october - april, be prepared to do a lot more work in the spring.
Rather than enroll in the class, consider just sitting in on the lectures. Find out what the instructor's expectations are before enrolling in the class.
If you don't mind writing papers, you might as well take it for 3 credits if the option is available.
I don't think I would recommend it to any other students.
Definitely do the 3-credit option. Start your research paper early, take the chance to ask for feedback from the instructors and TA.
Not sure if this course will be around in the future, but keep pushing for more and better urban offerings at Yale FES.
